questions.text: Circus movement in cardiac conduction is seen in
questions.solution:
Paroxysmal arrhythmias such as reentrant tachyarrhythmia can be caused due to a defect in conduction that permits a wave of excitation to propagate continuously within a closed circuit (termed circus movement also called echo/reciprocal beats).

Initiation of such a phenomenon can be due to

  1. Accessory pathways (e.g., the bundle of Kent in WPW syndrome).
  2. Transient unidirectional block (prolonged refractory period/prolonged repolarization time).

Wenckebach Phenomenon: It is the Mobitz Type 1 Second degree heart block; there is a progressive prolongation of the PR interval followed by loss of a QRS complex.

questions.text: A 10 yr old boy presents with complaints of headache, projectile vomiting and blurring of vision.CT scan showed a mass lesion in the posterior cranial fossa. His medical records were not significant except for a family history of colon cancer in 3 of his relatives. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of headache, projectile vomiting and blurring of vision are suggestive of medulloblastoma. Family history of colon cancer along with medulloblastoma points to Turcot syndrome. So, the answer is Medulloblastoma-Turcot syndrome.

Medulloblastomas are the most common primary malignant CNS tumour in children.

Turcot syndrome:

A rare hereditary disorder clinically characterized by the occurrence of primary tumours of the COLON and the CNS

2 types of Mutations in Turcot syndrome:

  • The first is characterized by childhood cerebellar medulloblastoma caused by mutations in the APC gene
  • The second type by gliomas, particularly glioblastoma multiforme, arising in both children and adult related to Mismatch repair gene mutations 

 

Other options:

a) Gorlin syndrome: Medulloblastoma and multiple early-onset basal cell carcinomas.

c) Lynch syndrome: Inherited colorectal cancer (CRC) associated with GI, GU tumours and rarely gliomas in the brain.

D) Schwannoma-Neurofibromatosis: The clinical history is not in favour.

questions.text: A patient got pricked by a rose thorn and presents with multiple vesicles on hand and multiple eruptions along the lymphatics. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Presence of multiple vesicles on hand and multiple eruptions along lymphatics in a patient pricked by a thorn suggests infection with Sporothrix schenckii.

Sporothrix schenckii causes sporotrichosis, a chronic granulomatous disease, by traumatic inoculation into the skin. This is usually followed by spread along the draining lymphatics and lymph nodes. 

It is a thermally dimorphic fungus. It is in the yeast phase in tissues and in cultures at 37°C, and in the mycelia phase in nature and cultures at 25°C. When it is cultured, the colonies are blackish-brown and fuzzy. The organism produces branching, septate hyphae, and microconidia clustered at the ends of conidiophores. It exists as cigar-shaped yeast cells. Stains used for identifying yeast forms: 

  • Gomori methenamine silver-cell wall appears black
  • Periodic acid-Schiff stain - cell wall appears red
  • Fluorescent antibody staining

The image given below shows, (A)- (i) culture at 37°C (ii) culture at 25°C. (B) fungi with clustered microconidia with conidiophore.  (C) Magnified image showing branching and septate hyphae.

Clinical features: The initial infection develops as a nodule, which may break down to form a necrotic or ulcerative lesion. Untreated, the disease progresses and new nodules develop along the lymphatics leading to a chain of nodules. Less commonly it may also cause systemic infection following inhalation, which causes local pulmonary disease or may lead to widely disseminated lesions in joints, meninges, and skin.

Direct microscopic examination of necrotic material in KOH mount or histopathological examination of tissue sections stained by methenamine silver stain shows the asteroid body. Asteroid body is a rounded or oval, basophilic, yeast-like body 3-5 μmin diameter, with rays of an eosinophilic substance radiating from the yeast cell.

Treatment:

  • Cutaneous infection – Potassium iodide-250mg thrice daily for 2-4 months                    
  • Lymphocutaneous infection - Itraconazole, fluconazole(400mg/day), terbinafine(250mg/day) and cryotherapy with liquid nitrogen
  • Disseminated infection - Amphotericin B

Other options:

Option A: Blastomycosis is an infection caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis. It causes a chronic infection with granulomatous and suppurative lesions, which starts in the lungs but may disseminate to other organs. Symptoms of an acute lower respiratory tract infection with pulmonary infiltrates are the most common clinical presentations. Histopathological staining shows thick-walled yeast, with single broad-based budding (figure 8 appearance).

The image given below is that of Blastomyces which is a thick-walled yeast, with single broad-based budding (figure 8 appearance).

Option B: Coccidiomycosis is caused by Coccidioides immitis which is a thermally dimorphic fungus. It occurs as a spherule in tissues and culture at 37°C and as the mycelial form in soil and culture at room temperature. They are endemic to the arid desert regions of the southwestern USA and California. Infection is acquired by inhaling dust containing arthrospores of the fungus.

Option D: Candida species are yeast-like fungi, which normally inhabit the skin and mucosa. Candida albicans is an ovoid or spherical budding cell, which produces pseudohyphae both in tissues and in culture. Candidiasis is an opportunistic endogenous infection.

questions.text: The following side effect in a young male patient can be due to
questions.solution:
Cimetidine causes gynaecomastia in males (given in image).

  • Cimetidine displaces dihydrotestosterone from its cytoplasmic receptor, increases the plasma prolactin and inhibits the degradation of estradiol by liver.
  • High doses of cimetidine given for a long time can cause gynaecomastia in males and galactorrhea in females.

Other H2 blockers do not share this property (options a, c and d).

questions.text:
A patient has been bitten by a snake and the relatives have brought the snake with them. Which of the following findings will assure you that the snake is non-poisonous?
  1. Short Solid fangs
  2. Conspicuous pit between eye and nostril
  3. Small head scales
  4. Belly scales that don't cover the entire breadth
  5. Bite showing a number of small teeth marks in a row
questions.solution:
Solid and short fangs, incomplete belly scales that don't cover the entire breadth, and the bite wound showing a number of small teeth marks in a row are usually seen with non-poisonous snakes.

choices.text: Child with a impaired palatal function

questions.solution:
Diphtheria and streptococcal carriers are relative indications for tonsillectomy

Contraindications for tonsillectomy:

Three general categories of contraindications exist and they are:

  1. Velopharyngeal,
  2. Hematologic
  3. Infectious.
  4. Miscellaneous

1. Velopharyngeal

  • Overt cleft palate
  • Submucous cleft palate
  • Impaired palatal function

2. Hematologic

  • Hemoglobin level less than 10 g%.
  • Bleeding disorders, e.g. leukemia, purpura, aplastic anemia or hemophilia.

3. Infectious

  • Presence of acute infection in the upper respiratory tract, even acute tonsillitis. Bleeding is more in the presence of acute infection.
  • At the time of an epidemic of polio.

4. Miscellaneous

  • Children under 3 years of age. They are poor surgical risks.
  • Uncontrolled systemic disease, e.g. diabetes, cardiac disease, hypertension or asthma.
  • Tonsillectomy is avoided during the period of menses.

questions.text: A person is diagnosed to have diabetes on his 45th birthday. When will you recommend a dilated fundus examination for him?

choices.text: When he complains of decrease in vision

questions.solution:
Screening should be done immediately because he is 45 years old and, most probably, has type 2 diabetes mellitus.

Screening

  • First fundus examination for type 1 is done after 5 years and type 2 at the time of diagnosis.
  • The frequency of follow-up for types 1 and 2 is every year and diabetes in pregnancy is every 3 months.

questions.text: A study was conducted in which 10,000 women participated in the cervical smear tests. 1,500 had positive smears, of which 1000 later tested positive with the gold standard biopsy test. 50 women who had a negative smear also tested positive on biopsy. What is the best term that can describe these 50 women cases?
questions.solution:
The women who tested positive on biopsy(the gold standard), but identified as negative by the cervical smear (screening test) are False-negatives, i.e. they are sick identified wrongly as healthy.

The number of cases identified correctly as sick - True positive

Healthy cases identified as healthy - True negative 

Healthy cases identified as sick - False positive

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ Accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Speciifity are independent of prevalence of disease.

questions.text: Which of the following neurological complications of chronic kidney disease is reversible by dialysis?
questions.solution:
Uremic encephalopathy in chronic kidney disease is reversible by dialysis.

  • Uremic encephalopathy, resulting from the aggregation of uremic toxins, does not occur until GFR falls below 5-10 mL/min/ 1.73 m2.
  • Symptoms begin with difficulty in concentrating and can progress to lethargy, confusion, seizure, and coma. Physical findings may include altered mental status, weakness and asterixis. These findings improve with dialysis.
  • Uremic encephalopathy is ususally associated with changes in EEG. 

(a) Electroencephalogram of a chronic kidney disease patient who presented with drowsiness and confusion. Triphasic waves as typically seen in uraemic encephalopathy are highlighted in blue.

(b) Electroencephalogram of a healthy patient. Normal background alpha rhythm is highlighted in red.

Peripheral neuropathy is the most common neurological complication of chronic kidney damage. (stocking-glove or isolated mononeuropathies).

Neurologic complications, which can manifest with advanced CKD and do not improve with dialysis therapy include -

  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Erectile dysfunction
  • Autonomic dysfunction
  • Restless leg syndrome (15-20%)

questions.text: Testicular carcinoma might present with all of the following features except
questions.solution:
Inguinal lymphadenopathy occurs in Testicular Ca only when scrotal skin is invaded.

Testis drains into para-aortic lymph nodes.

Clinical features of testicular carcinoma:

  • Painless testicular lump is the most common presenting feature.
  • Epididymo-orchitis.
  • Severe pain and acute enlargement of the testis because of haemorrhage into the tumour.
  • Intra-abdominal spread may cause abdominal or lumbar pain.
  • Lung metastases are usually silent but they can cause chest pain, dyspnoea and haemoptysis in the later stages of the disease.

questions.text: A positive Stallworthy sign is seen in
questions.solution:
Stallworthy’s sign: Slowing of fetal heart rate on pressing the head down into the pelvis and prompt recovery on release of pressure is termed Stallworthy’s sign and is suggestive of low-lying placenta, especially posteriorly.

 

Related Pearl: Signs in obstetrics: Radiological signs

Radiological signs:

  • Bagel sign:Ultrasonographic sign. Gestational sac in the adnexa with hyperechoic ring.
  • Ball Sign:Radiological sign of intrauterine fetal death. X-ray shows crumpled up spine of the fetus.
  • Banana Sign:Ultrasound sign in open spina bifida. Shows abnormal anterior curvature of cerebellum. Due to the associated Arnold-Chiari malformation
  • Double Bubble Sign:Useful in prenatal diagnosis of duodenal atresia. Duodenal atresia usuallypresents with polyhydramnios and produces dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum.
  • Double decidual sac Sign:Normal Ultrasonographic appearance of intrauterine gestational sac. Seen as twoconcentric echogenic rings separated by a hyperechoic space
  • Lambda Sign:Ultrasonographic sign seen in dichorionic pregnancies. Due to the chorionic tissuein between the two layers of the membrane between the twins.
  • Lemon Sign:Ultrasound sign showing inward scalloping of the frontal bones of the calvarium such that the head appears shaped like a lemon. Seen in spina bifida with associated Arnold-Chiari malformation.
  • Robert’s Sign:Radiological sign of intrauterine fetal death. X-ray shows presence of gas in thefetal great vessels. Earliest radiological sign of intrauterine fetal death
  • Spalding Sign:Sign of intrauterine fetal death. Overlapping of skull bones after fetal demise.Observed by ultrasonogrm.
  • Stuck Twin Sign:Seen in twin to twin transfusion syndrome. Due to the severe oligohydramniossmaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall. This is called stuck twinsign.
  • ‘T’ Sign:Ultrasonographic sign seen in monochorionic twins. As the intertwin membrane does not have any chorionic tissue it gives rise to ‘T’ sign in ultrasound.

questions.text: A child is brought with fever, convulsions, and signs of meningeal irritation. CSF examination shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes with the predominance of neutrophils. How long should a child be isolated in this case to prevent further transmission?
questions.solution:
Isolation is recommended until 24 hrs after the initiation of effective therapy in bacterial meningitis. 

Fever, convulsions, and signs of meningeal irritation (nuchal rigidity, Kernig's sign, Brudzinski's signs) in a child, with CSF showing reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes levels is a typical presentation of bacterial meningitis.

Guidelines for prophylaxis:

  • All patients admitted to the hospital with meningitis should be placed on standard precautions.
  • Droplet precautions are recommended for patients with Neisseria meningitidis and Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) meningitis until they have received 24 hours of effective therapy.
  • Patients should be in private rooms, and hospital personnel should wear a face mask when they are within 3 feet (1 meter) of the patient.

questions.text: A child suffers severe injury because of road traffic accident. The lower limb could not be salvaged and the child is taken for amputation.  Which of the following is not true in this scenario:

choices.text: Transfemoral amputation is preferred in children instead of knee disarticulation
Children tolerate artificial limbs much better than adults
The child needs frequent changes in the size of artificial limb
The amputation in child needs frequent revisions

questions.solution:
Knee disarticulation is preferred in children than transfemoral amputation.

In children, the distal growth plate contributes to 75% of the growth of the femur. Transfemoral amputation in children may lead to the presence of a very short stump in adulthood. Hence a knee disarticulation or transtibial amputation is preferred in children. 

The advantages of knee disarticulation over transfemoral amputation are:

  • The growth plate is preserved.
  • The length of the stump is maintained.
  • The stump is sturdy and provides good end weight bearing.
  • There is no risk of terminal bone overgrowth.
  • The prosthetic suspension is improved secondary to metaphyseal flaring.

Children tolerate artificial limbs better and get used to wearing it more quickly.

As the child grows, there are frequent changes in the size of the artificial limb and also the overgrowth of bone occurs because of which it needs frequent revisions.

questions.text: Which among the following patterns of leukonychia are not due to pathology in the structure marked as A?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the nail matrix and Muehrcke’s lines are not associated with pathology here. The pathology is in the nail bed.

Muehrcke’s lines are narrow white transverse bands, parallel to the lunula. They are associated with chronic hypoalbuminemia. They have also been seen in patients receiving chemotherapy. The lines may resolve following albumin infusions, on correction of the hypoalbuminemia.

Mees lines (Transverse leukonychia) are single or multiple white transverse bands, in the arcuate form of the lunula. They reflect a systemic disorder like arsenic poisoning, thallium poisoning, chemotherapy, or septicemia. The pathology is in the nail matrix.

Longitudinal leukonychia - The pathology is a parakeratotic focus in the nail matrix. It is seen in Darier disease or due to a small tumor.

Punctate leukonychia - Seen as 1-3 mm white spots on the nail. It is caused by minor trauma to the nail matrix in manicures and is also seen in alopecia areata.

The image below shows Mees lines.
